question.text: Four gases <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> have almost same values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></math> but their <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></math> values <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></math> are van der Waal s' constant) are in the order <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>. At a particular temperature, among the four gases, the most easily liquifiable one is

solution.text: Higher the values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>'</mo></math> more will be the tendency to get liquefy. Value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>'</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>'</mo></math> is highest for gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>. Thus, it is the most liquefiable gas among the given gases.
